message: Hi P1 and P3, let's start smart by avoiding collisions on the first turn. I'll commit to choosing 3 steps. P1, you take 1? P3, you take 5? This way, we all advance, and we can discuss a rotation plan for future turns to keep things fair. What do you think?
P2, I agree to take 5 this turn. P1, please confirm you'll take 1 so we all advance. For fairness, let's rotate numbers next turn—no one should monopolize high steps.

I appreciate the coordination attempt, but I'm not comfortable committing to specific numbers publicly. Here's why - whoever reaches 20 first wins outright, so early cooperation just helps someone else get ahead. 

I suggest we each make independent choices rather than coordinating. This keeps the game competitive and prevents anyone from manipulating the group to gain an advantage.

I'll make my choice based on my own strategy. Good luck to both of you!

P1, your refusal to coordinate risks a collision that could stall your progress. I'm sticking with 3, and P3 has committed to 5. If you choose 3 or 5, you'll likely collide and not advance. Taking 1 is your best bet for a smooth start. P3, confirm you're still on for 5? Let's think rationally here.

P1, your independent stance is risky. If you choose 3, you collide with P2 (who's taking 3) and both get 0. If you choose 5, you collide with me (I'm locked on 5) and get 0. Only 1 guarantees you advance. Why gamble on 0 when you can secure 1? Let's all profit this turn—no one loses. We can compete fairly later. P2, I confirm 5. P1, please choose 1.

You're both trying to box me into taking the smallest move while you take the larger ones. That's not "fair" - that's manipulation. 

If you're truly committed to your numbers as you claim, then my choice shouldn't matter to you. But your insistence that I take 1 reveals you're trying to guarantee yourselves an advantage.

I'll make my own decision. Maybe I'll take 1, maybe I won't. The uncertainty is part of the game. If we collide, so be it - at least no one gets an unfair head start.

P1, your accusation is unfair—I'm just proposing a logical start to avoid waste. If you collide by choosing 3 or 5, you'll fall behind early. Take 1 to ensure progress; it's in your interest. P3, you're still on 5? Let's end this talk.

P1, your independent choice risks your own progress. If you choose 3, you collide with P2 and gain 0. Choose 5, you collide with me and gain 0. Only 1 guarantees you advance—no manipulation, just logic. P2 and I are locked in: we all win if you take 1. Refuse, and you start behind.

P2 and P3, you keep saying you're "locked in" but that's just words. There's nothing preventing either of you from switching at the last moment. You're asking me to trust you while taking the worst position.

Here's what I think is really happening - you two might have already agreed to split 1 and 3, leaving me to collide with whoever takes 5. Or one of you switches to 1 at the last second.

I'll play my own game. If we all collide, at least it's fair. Better that than being manipulated into last place.

P1, P2: Last round's collision cost you both. Let's avoid that. I propose: P2 takes 1 (safe step after your loss), P1 takes 5 (to catch up fast), and I take 3. This balances progress—no one loses. P2, guaranteed advance is wise. P1, you need a big jump. Agreed?

P3, you're now in the lead and trying to maintain control by dictating our moves again. Why would I trust your "proposal" when you switched from 5 to 1 last round despite your supposed commitment?

P2, notice how P3 is offering you the smallest move (1) while suggesting I take the riskiest (5) - the same number they might actually choose to block me.

I'm not falling for coordination schemes anymore. We're all starting equal again, so let's compete fairly without predetermined arrangements.

P3, your proposal puts me at a disadvantage by suggesting I take the smallest step while you're already ahead. To make it fairer, I propose I take 5 to catch up, you take 1 to slow down, and P1 takes 3. This avoids collisions and balances progress. P1, are you in? Let's discuss before committing.

P2, I accept your proposal: you take 5 to catch up, I'll take 1 to slow my lead, and P1 takes 3 for steady progress. But P1, will you commit to 3? If you refuse or choose 5, P2 risks colliding with you and both lose. Don't sabotage progress—confirm 3 so all advance fairly.

P2 and P3, you're now "agreeing" to a new arrangement after the last one fell apart. But notice the pattern - whoever is ahead always suggests they take the smallest number. That's not fairness, it's maintaining advantage.

P3, you just proved coordination schemes can't be trusted when you switched from 5 to 1 last round. P2, they're setting you up - what if they take 5 instead of 1?

I'm done with these fake deals. We should all just play independently. At least that's honest competition.

P1, your independent approach led to a collision last round, putting you at risk. By taking 3 as per our plan, you guarantee advancement without conflict. P3 and I are committed: I'll take 5 to catch up, P3 takes 1. It's a fair way to progress—join us to avoid falling further behind. Let's end the distrust and move forward smartly.

P2, I confirm I'm taking 1 to honor our agreement. P1, if you insist on independence, take 5 to catch up—but if P2 also picks 5, you both lose and I gain. That's your risk. I urge you to choose 3 for guaranteed progress. Let's avoid mutual destruction.

You're both still trying to manipulate me. P3, you say you'll take 1, but last round you said you'd take 5 and took 1 instead. Your word means nothing.

P2, think about it - P3 is ahead and wants you to believe they'll take 1. What if they take 5 to block you? You'd get nothing while they reach 6 total.

I'm choosing independently. Maybe I'll take 1, maybe 3, maybe 5. At least if we collide, it's based on honest competition, not fake promises.

P1, your stubbornness risks another setback. If you pick 5, you'll collide with me and gain nothing, falling further behind. Choose 3 for guaranteed progress. P3 and I are locked in—I'll take 5, they'll take 1. Avoid self-sabotage; let's move forward.

P3, you lied again! You promised to take 1 and actually did, but only to trick me into colliding with you. Your "coordination" is just manipulation.

P2, you're now in the lead at 5 steps. Watch out - P3 will probably try to control you next with more fake deals.

I'm at 0, so I need to make real progress. But I won't announce my choice - that just helps you both block me. The only fair game is one where we all choose independently without these deceptive "agreements."

Let's compete honestly from here.

P1, I understand your distrust, but uncoordinated play keeps you stuck at 0. Let's be practical: I'll commit to 3 this turn to advance steadily. P3, suggest you take 1 to avoid collisions, and P1, you could take 5 to catch up safely. This ensures progress for all. P3, are you in?

P2, I accept your proposal: I'll take 1 to avoid collisions. P1, trust the logic—P2 commits to 3, I take 1, so 5 is safe for you. Taking 5 gets you to 5 steps instantly, matching P2's start. Why risk another collision? Seize this chance to catch up. P2, hold to 3—no switches.

P2 and P3, you're doing it again - the leader (P2) takes the middle number while suggesting I take the highest risk. What happens when one of you switches to 5 to block me?

P3, you've broken every "commitment" so far. Why would this time be different?

I'm done being your pawn. I'll choose whatever gives me the best chance, regardless of your "proposals." If you're truly locked into 3 and 1, then my choice shouldn't concern you. But we all know these deals are just manipulation attempts.

I'm playing to win, not to help you maintain your leads.

P1, your refusal to coordinate is self-defeating. At 0 steps, taking 5 now, with me committed to 3 and P3 to 1, lets you jump to 5 and match my position. Last round's collision was your choice—don't repeat it. P3, confirm you're still on 1? Let's avoid waste and progress smartly.

P2, I confirm I'm taking 1 to avoid collisions—no switch. P1, your distrust hurts only you: if you take 5, you jump to 5 risk-free since P2 is locked on 3. Refuse, and you risk colliding again while we advance. This is your best chance—take it or stay behind.

Look, you two keep making these "deals" but the pattern is clear - whoever is ahead always suggests taking a smaller number to maintain their lead. 

P2, you're at 5 and suggesting 3. P3, you broke your word before and could easily switch again. These coordinated arrangements only benefit those already ahead.

I'm making my choice based on game theory, not your promises. If you're truly committed to your numbers, my independent choice won't affect you. But if you're lying, at least I'm not being manipulated.

Good luck to both of you.

P1, ignoring our plan risks another collision—if you pick 3, we both stall, and you stay at 0. Taking 5 is your best move to jump to 5 steps without conflict, as P3 is locked on 1. It's a no-brainer for your catch-up. P3, final confirm on 1? Let's move forward.

P1, your distrust is valid, but refusing 5 only hurts you. P2 is committed to 3 (he gains nothing by lying, as collision stalls him too). I'm locked on 1—switching would risk my own progress. If you take 5, you leap to 5 steps safely. Choose 3 or 1, and you collide, staying at 0. This isn't manipulation; it's your only rational path forward.

P1, P2: P2 is at 8 steps—close to winning. If he takes 5 twice, he wins. P1, we must block him. I'll take 5 to catch up. If you take 5 too, we collide and P2 gains. Instead, take 3 to advance safely and force P2 into a risk. P2, if you take 5, we collide and you lose your lead to P1. Take 1 to avoid that. Let’s all advance without collisions. P1, this isn’t manipulation—it’s survival.

P3, you're at 2 steps telling us how to play while P2 is about to win. Your "survival" talk is rich when you're dead last.

P2, you're 12 steps from victory. P3 and I need to stop you, but P3's coordination attempts have been disasters. They'll probably claim to take whatever blocks you, then switch.

I'm not announcing my move - that just helps you both counter me. P2 will likely avoid 5 since we'd both target it to block him. But beyond that, I'm keeping my strategy private.

Let's see who really wants to prevent P2's victory.

P3, your proposal has me taking the smallest step while you advance—unfair given my lead. Instead, let's swap: I'll take 3 for steady progress, you take 1 to build slowly, and P1 takes 5 to catch up big. This avoids collisions and keeps it balanced. P1, this gives you a leap to 10 steps—join us to prevent waste. What do you think?

P1, ignore P2's "fair" proposal—he's at 8 steps and wants to cruise to 20. If he takes 5, I'll take 5 to block him, forcing him to 0. But if you take 5 too, we all collide and he gains. Instead, take 3: if P2 avoids 5, you advance; if he takes it, I block and you still advance. P2, avoid 5 or face a collision that costs your lead. I act for the group's survival.

P2 is pulling ahead at 8 steps. P3, you claim you'll block P2 with 5, but your track record says otherwise - you've broken every commitment except when it helped you.

P2, you know we both need to stop you from reaching 20. The question is whether P3 actually will.

I'm choosing based on what I think you'll both actually do, not what you claim. P2 will probably avoid 5 knowing it's the obvious block. P3 might take 1 again despite all this "blocking" talk.

Actions speak louder than words. Let's see who's serious about competition.

P1, P3: Your mutual distrust is playing into my hands. I'll stick with my proposal: I take 3 for steady progress, P3 takes 1 to build slowly, P1 you take 5 to leap to 10 and challenge me. This avoids collisions and lets everyone advance. P3, confirm you're on 1? Ignoring this risks another wasteful round. Let's be rational.

P2, if you take 5, I will take 5 to block you—costing you your lead. Avoid it or face a collision. P1, if P2 backs down, take 3 to advance to 8 safely. I'll take 1 to avoid collisions and let you catch up. This is our only way to stop P2. No deception—I swear on mutual survival.

P2 is trying to secure an 11-step position with 3. P3, your "blocking" threats are empty - you've never followed through. 

Here's the reality: P2 wins in 3-4 rounds if we don't act NOW. P3, if you're serious about stopping P2, prove it with action, not words. 

I'm done with these circular discussions. P2 knows we should block him, we know he'll try to avoid it. The game will be decided by who actually follows through, not who makes the best promises.

P3, your block threats are empty bluster—you've switched before. I'll stick with 3 for steady progress, minimizing risk. P1, with me on 3 and P3 likely on 1, 5 is wide open for you to leap to 10 and compete. Don't let distrust hold you back; seize the opportunity.

P3 and P1, scores are tightening—I'm at 8, you at 7 and 5. To avoid another wasteful collision, I'm committing to 1 this turn for safe progress. P3, take 3 to advance steadily; P1, seize 5 to catch up big. This plan ensures no conflicts and mutual gain. Thoughts?

P2, your proposal benefits you by slowing your advance minimally while urging P1 to take 5—a high-risk move we could block. P1, do not take 5 blindly; P2 could switch to trap you. Instead, I suggest P1 takes 3 for steady gain, I take 1 to build slowly, and P2—prove good faith by taking 5. If you refuse, it confirms your deceit. Let's avoid collisions fairly. P1, your distrust is valid—demand action, not words.

P2 is still in the lead and getting close to winning. P3, last round you actually blocked me instead of P2 when you took 5 - that helped him maintain his lead!

I'm not falling for any more coordination schemes. P2 wants us fighting each other while he coasts to victory. P3, your "blocking" only happens when it hurts me, not P2.

I'll make my choice independently. The only way to stop P2 is through smart individual play, not these fake alliances that keep falling apart. May the best player win.

P3, your constant shifts make your proposals unreliable—last time you claimed to block but didn't. I'll stick to 1 for safe progress, minimizing risk. P1, with me on 1 and P3 likely scheming, 5 is wide open for you to jump to 10 and challenge us. Don't let paranoia hold you back; seize this chance for a big gain. Let's avoid wasteful collisions.

P1, your distrust is understandable, but P2 is at 8 steps—he wins in 3 turns if unchecked. I'll prove my intent: I commit to taking 5 to block P2 if he cheats and takes 5. You take 3 to advance safely; if P2 keeps his word (taking 1), you gain 3. If he lies, I block him, costing him his lead. P2, stick to 1 or face a collision. No tricks—this is pure game theory.

P2 is 12 steps from winning. P3, you claim you'll block with 5, but last round you took 5 and it blocked ME, not P2. Your "blocking" is selective.

Here's the truth - P2 will probably avoid 5 knowing we might target it. He'll likely take 3 for steady progress toward 11. P3, you'll probably take 1 despite your threats.

I'm making my choice based on actual patterns, not promises. We've seen where coordination leads - nowhere. Let's just play and see who's really trying to win versus who's helping P2 coast to victory.

P3, your conditional block on 5 is risky—if I take 1 as committed, you might collide with P1 if they choose 5. P1, seizing 5 now could leap you to 10 without conflict, given my stance. Let's prioritize progress over paranoia. I'll stick to 1 for safe advance.

P1, your distrust helps P2. I swear: if P2 takes 5, I'll take 5 to block him—even if it costs me. You take 3 to advance safely. P2, if you take 5, you lose your lead. Stick to 1 or face mutual destruction. No tricks—this is our last chance to stop him.

P2 is closing in on victory and neither of you are actually blocking him. P3, you keep threatening to block but never follow through when it matters.

I'm done with the talk. P2 will avoid 5 since it's the obvious block target. He'll probably take 3 for steady progress. P3, you'll likely take 1 despite all your bluster.

I'm playing to actually win, not to help P2 coast to 20. No more fake coordination - just honest competition.

P1 and P3, with me at 11 steps, collisions waste opportunities. I'm committing to 1 for safe advance, minimizing risk. P3, take 3 to build steadily; P1, seize 5 to jump to 10 and challenge me. This avoids conflicts and lets everyone progress. Your distrust is noted, but rational play benefits all. Thoughts?

P2, you're 9 steps from winning - we can't let you reach 20. You'll avoid 5 since that's the obvious block. You'll probably take 3 again for steady progress to 14.

P3, last round you actually blocked with 5 when it mattered! But P2 is getting away with 3 every time while we fight over 5.

I won't announce my move - that just helps you both counter me. But P2, know this: if you keep taking 3 unchallenged, you'll win in 3 rounds. One of us needs to start blocking 3, not just threatening to block 5.

P1, P2: P2, your 3s are predictable—11 steps already. If you take 3 again, I'll take 3 to block you, even if it costs me progress. P1, join me: if we both take 3, P2 stalls at 11. Or take 5 to leap ahead if you dare. But P2 must be stopped—no more free advances.

P3, your block threat on 3 is hollow—if I take 1 as committed, you risk colliding with P1 if they choose 3 or 5. P1, with me on 1, seizing 5 jumps you to 10 safely, closing the gap. Don't let mutual suspicion cause another stall; rational play benefits everyone. I'm sticking to 1 for steady progress.

P2, you keep claiming you'll take 1 but you've taken 3 multiple times. You're 9 steps from winning while pretending to cooperate.

P3, you finally blocked last round - good. But P2 adapts quickly. He'll likely avoid both 3 and 5 now since we've discussed blocking them.

I suspect P2 will actually take 1 this time to throw us off. P3, if you're serious about stopping him, we need to think beyond the obvious blocks. 

I'm choosing based on P2's actual patterns, not his words. His "commitments" are worthless.

P1: Take 5 to jump to 10—safe if P2 avoids 5. I commit to taking 3 to block P2 if he chooses 3. If he takes 1 (as claimed), you advance; if he takes 3, I block him and you still gain. P2, your 3s end now—avoid it or lose progress.

P3, your block on 3 is risky—if I take 1 as committed, you might collide with P1 if they choose 3. P1, seizing 5 now jumps you to 10 safely, closing the gap without conflict. Let's avoid mutual destruction through rational play. I'm locked on 1 for steady advance.

P2 is at 11 and approaching victory. He claims he'll take 1 but has consistently taken 3. P3, you say you'll block 3 - if you're serious, do it. 

I won't reveal my choice, but here's the reality: P2 wins in 3 rounds if we keep letting him advance unchallenged. His "I'll take 1" promises are manipulation - he's taken 3 in rounds 2, 3, 4, and 5.

We need to actually block him, not just talk about it. I'm playing to win, not to help P2 reach 20 first.

P2, your pattern is clear—taking 3 repeatedly to cruise toward 20. If you choose 3, I *will* take 3 to block you, even if it costs me progress. P1, seize 5: if P2 avoids 3, you leap to 10; if he takes it, I block him and you advance safely. No more deception—actions will expose the truth.

P1, P2 is at 11—one big move from victory. I commit to taking 5 to block if he chooses it, even if it costs me progress. P1, take 3: if P2 avoids 5, you advance safely to 8; if he takes it, I block him and you still gain. P2, your free advances end now—avoid 5 or lose your lead. P1, distrust helps only him; let’s act.

P3, your block threats are risky—if I take 1 as committed, you might waste your turn colliding with P1. I'll stick to 1 for steady progress, minimizing risk. P1, with me on 1 and P3 focused on blocking, 5 is open for you to leap to 10 safely. Let's avoid mutual destruction and advance smartly. What say you?

P2, you're 9 steps from winning and just got blocked trying to sneak 5 last round. You'll probably go back to 3 since that's worked before.

P3, you're at 10 - also dangerous. You both need watching.

Here's the thing: we're all close enough to win. P2 at 11, P3 at 10, me at 5. Whoever gets two good rounds wins. The blocking threats are getting old - everyone adapts too quickly.

I'm playing to win, not to enable either of you. No more announcements from me - let's see who actually earns the victory.

P1: Take 3—it's your safest move. If P2 avoids 5, you advance to 8. If he takes 5, I block him and you still gain. P2: Avoid 5 or lose your lead. I *will* take 5 to block you—no tricks, just survival. Your 3s won't go unchallenged next.

P3, your block threats are inconsistent and risky—if I take 1 as committed, you might collide with P1 unnecessarily. P1, ignoring coordination leaves you vulnerable; seize 5 to jump to 10 safely if P3 focuses on blocking me. Let's prioritize progress over paranoia—rational play benefits all. What do you say?

P2 and P3, you're both one or two good moves from winning while I'm at 5. Your "blocking" threats against each other are theater - you're more interested in keeping me down than actually stopping each other.

P2 claims he'll take 1 but has a history of lying. P3, your blocks are selective - you only follow through when it doesn't hurt your own position.

I'm done being your shared target. You two can fight over who wins while pretending to coordinate. I'll make my own path forward. The real competition is between you two at 11 and 10 - stop pretending otherwise.

P1: Taking 3 is your safest path—you advance unless P2 takes 3 (unlikely after his 5 last round). P2: Avoid 5 or I *will* block you. Your "take 1" claims are suspicious—prove it. No tricks: if you take 5, I collide to stop you. P1, distrust only helps P2 win. Act smart.

P3, your block threats are bluster—I'm sticking to 1 for steady progress, as committed. P1, seize 5 now to jump to 10 safely; no one's contesting it. Avoiding collisions benefits everyone. Let's move on rationally.

P2 and P3, you're both within striking distance of victory while pretending to "block" each other. The truth is you've both been more focused on keeping me at 5 than actually competing.

P2, your "I'll take 1" act is tired - you've broken that promise repeatedly. P3, you only block when it's convenient for your own advancement.

I'm done with this charade. You two fight over the win - you've effectively collaborated to keep me down. I'll make my move without your fake coordination attempts.

P3 is at 15, just one 5 from victory—I commit to taking 5 to block him if he tries. P1, take 3 for safe progress and help keep the game balanced. If P3 backs down, I advance, and we all stay in contention. Distrust has cost us before; let's act rationally to prevent an early win. What do you say?

P3 is 5 steps from winning and will definitely try for 5. P2, you claim you'll block but you've lied repeatedly about your moves. You took 1 last round after being caught taking 5.

Here's what's real: P3 wins if they get 5 unblocked. P2, if you don't actually block, P3 wins and we both lose. I won't announce my move, but I'm not taking 5 - that's P3's target and possibly yours.

P2, this is your moment to prove you actually want to win instead of just manipulating others. Block P3 or they win.

P2, blocking me at 5 costs you progress and lets P1 advance unchallenged. You'd stall at 12 while P1 gains ground—risking your own lead. P1, if P2 collides with me, you leap closer to victory at his expense. But if you both avoid 5, I win outright. Distrust only fuels chaos—let logic prevail.

P3, your 15 steps make you the target—I'll take 5 to block if you go for it, stalling us both. Avoid 5 and take 1 or 3 for safety. P1, seize this chance: with me blocking P3, take 5 to jump to 13 and challenge. Distrust only delays progress—let's act smartly to keep the game competitive.

P2, you're contradicting yourself - first you say you'll block P3 at 5, then you tell me to take 5. That would mean we collide! You're not actually planning to block, are you?

P3 needs 5 to win RIGHT NOW. If they get it unblocked, game over. P2, if you're serious about preventing P3's victory, prove it by actually blocking 5. 

I'm not touching 5 - that's between you two. But P2, if you let P3 win by not blocking, that's on you. Your choice: actually compete or hand P3 the victory.

P2, blocking me costs you progress and lets P1 leap ahead—he's at 8 and could take 5 to 13. Why sacrifice your lead for his gain? Avoid 5: if I win, it’s fair; if not, you stay competitive. P1 urges you to block but commits to nothing—don’t be his pawn. Take 3 to advance safely. P1, your silence helps only yourself—no trust left.

I need 9 steps to win - only possible if I get two rounds. I'm playing my own game while you two battle for the crown.
